title-group.article-title: Gadolinium chloride pretreatment ameliorates acute cadmium-induced hepatotoxicity

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Experimental Pharmacology, Medical School, Athens University, Athens, Greece
2Histopathology Laboratory, Sismanoglion G.D. Hospital, Marousi, Attiki, Greece
3Department of Nursing, University of Peloponnese, Orthias Artemidos and Plateon, Sparta, Lakonia, Greece

author-notes.corresp: Georgios I Panoutsopoulos, Department of Nursing, University of Peloponnese, Orthias Artemidos and Plateon, Sparta, Lakonia 23100, Greece. Email: geopanou@otenet.gr

abstract.p: Cadmium is a known industrial and environmental pollutant. It causes hepatotoxicity upon acute administration. Features of cadmium-induced acute hepatoxicity encompass necrosis, apoptosis, peliosis and inflammatory infiltration. Gadolinium chloride (GdCl3) may prevent cadmium-induced hepatotoxicity by suppressing Kupffer cells. The effect of GdCl3 pretreatment on a model of acute cadmium-induced liver injury was investigated. Male Wistar rats 4–5 months old were injected intraperitoneally with normal saline followed by cadmium chloride (CdCl2; 6.5 mg/kg) or GdCl3 (10 mg/kg) followed by CdCl2 (6.5 mg/kg; groups I and II, respectively). Rats of both the groups were killed at 9, 12, 16, 24, 48 and 60 h after cadmium intoxication. Liver sections were analyzed for necrosis, apoptosis, peliosis and mitoses. Liver regeneration was also evaluated by tritiated thymidine incorporation into hepatic DNA. Serum levels of aspartate aminotransferase (AST) and alanine aminotransferase (ALT) were also determined. Hepatic necrosis, hepatocyte and nonparenchymal cell apoptosis and macroscopic and microscopic types of peliosis hepatis were minimized by gadolinium pretreatment. Serum levels of AST and ALT were also greatly diminished in rats of group II. Tritiated thymidine incorporation into hepatic DNA was increased in gadolinium pretreatment rats. Kupffer cell activation was minimal in both the groups of rats. Gadolinium pretreatment attenuates acute cadmium-induced liver injury in young Wistar rats, with mechanisms other than Kupffer cell elimination.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Cadmium is one of the most abundant nonessential toxic elements due to its immense usage in various industrial applications (Page et al., 1986). In humans, the primary route of exposure is via contaminated drinking water, food supplies and tobacco (Goering et al., 1995). Acute cadmium intoxication in experimental animals results primarily in the accumulation of the metal in the liver causing acute hepatotoxicity (Dudley et al., 1982; Kotsonis and Klaassen, 1977). Histopathological features of cadmium toxicity in the liver include zonal, focal and massive necrosis, fatty infiltration and hepatocyte swelling (Dudley et al., 1982, 1984). Apoptosis of parenchymal and nonparenchymal liver cells also constitutes a major mode of cell death in acute cadmium-induced hepatotoxicity (Tzirogiannis et al., 2003).

Peliosis hepatis is a vascular lesion characterized by the formation of blood-filled cavities with or without endothelial cell lining (Tzirogiannis et al., 2006; Wold, 1981) and represents a distinct histological finding in cadmium acute hepatotoxicity (Tzirogiannis et al., 2003, 2006). Peliosis is further subdivided into microscopic and macroscopic types, and endothelial cell apoptosis seems to be the major mode of cell death implicated in the genesis of the lesion in the livers of cadmium intoxicated rats (Tzirogiannis et al., 2003, 2006).

Cadmium is considered to act not only directly on hepatocytes and nonparenchymal liver cells causing toxicity but also indirectly through activation of Kupffer cells (Rikans and Yamano, 2000). Endothelial cells appear to be the most sensitive liver cell subpopulation to the toxic effects of the metal (Liu et al., 1992; McKim et al., 1992; Nolan and Shaikh, 1986). In Wistar rats, liver injury caused by cadmium has been reported to be age dependent and rats less than 6 months old are resistant to the toxic effects of the metal through reduced activation of Kupffer cells and neutrophil infiltration (Tzirogiannis et al., 2003; Yamano et al., 1998, 2000).

Cadmium acute hepatotoxicity has been the subject of numerous reports, and it has been proposed that it evolves as a biphasic process that encompasses two distinct pathways: one for initial injury mainly through direct toxic effects of the metal and/or ischemia due to endothelial cell injury and the other for delayed injury due to the triggering of the inflammatory cascade (Dong et al., 1998; Kayama et al., 1995; Rikans and Yamano, 2000; Sauer et al., 1997). Tumor necrosis factor α (TNF-α), mainly a product of Kupffer cells, has been considered a pivotal growth factor-mediating cadmium-induced liver injury, although TNF-α-null mice also develop severe liver trauma following cadmium intoxication (Harstad and Klaassen, 2002a).

Gadolinium is a pleiotropic lanthanide that specifically eliminates Kupffer cells (Sauer et al., 1997). Pretreatment with gadolinium chloride (GdCl3) prevents cadmium-induced hepatotoxicity, and this action seems to be independent of Kupffer cell elimination or induction of metallothionine (MT) since it is also present in MT null mice (Harstad and Klaassen, 2002b). Gadolinium protective action against cadmium is observed only on intact liver since the metal does not protect cultured hepatocytes (Badger et al., 1997).

Gadolinium has also been reported to protect against carbon tetrachloride-induced liver injury (Edwards et al., 1993) and against ischemia–reperfusion injury by inhibiting apoptosis (Li et al., 2009). Gadolinium pretreatment also arrests the apoptosis of liver cells after radiation (Du et al., 2010). In the present study, we investigated the effect of GdCl3 pretreatment on acute cadmium-induced hepatotoxicity.

sec.title: Chemicals
sec.p: Cadmium chloride (CdCl2) and GdCl3 were supplied from Sigma-Aldrich Chemical Company Inc (St. Louis, MO, USA). Diethyl ether for anesthesia was obtained from Codex, Carlo Erba (Milan, Italy) and [3H]-thymidine from Amersham Corp (Buckinghamshire, UK). TUNEL assay (terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase dUTP nick-end labeling) was purchased from YLEM (Roma, Italy) and APC Detection Kit from NeoMarkers (Freemont, CA, USA).

sec.title: Animals and treatment
sec.p: Male Wistar rats (Hellenic Pasteur Institute, Athens, Greece) 4–5 months old, weighing 160–180 g, were used in this study. The animals were fed with a commercial pelleted diet and tap water. They were allowed food and water ad libitum and maintained in identical housing units under controlled temperature (22 ± 1°C) and lighting cycle (8:00 a.m.–8:00 p.m. light and 8:00 p.m.–8:00 a.m. dark). Animals were handled with humane care in accordance with the European Union Directive and adapted in the relevant Greek Presidential decree (Greek presidential decree No 160/1991, 1991). All experiments were conducted between 7.00 and 9.30 a.m., with the animals under light ether anesthesia.

Animals were randomly selected and assigned into two groups as follows:
Group I rats: intraperitoneal injection of CdCl2 at a dose of 6.5 mg/kg body weight and intraperitoneal injection of normal saline 24 h prior to cadmium intoxication.
Group II rats: intraperitoneal injection of CdCl2 at a dose of 6.5 mg/kg body weight and intraperitoneal injection of GdCl3 at the dose of 10 mg/kg body weight 24 h prior to cadmium intoxication.

Animals from all groups were killed under ether anesthesia via cardiac puncture at 9, 12, 16, 24, 48 and 60 h after cadmium intoxication. The control group consisted of a group of six animals killed at 0 h. One hour prior to killing, the animals of all groups were injected with [3H]-thymidine at a dose of 250 μCi/kg body weight intraperitoneally.

sec.title: Histopathology
sec.p: Blocks of liver tissue were fixed in 4% buffered formalin for 24 h, paraffin-embedded, stained with hematoxylin–eosin (H&E) and assessed for necrosis, apoptosis, peliosis, mitoses and inflammatory infiltration.

Necrosis was assessed semiquantitatively in a 5-degree severity scale (0–4): 0: no necrosis; 1: necrosis of 1%–5% of liver cells; 2: necrosis of 6%–25% of liver cells; 3: necrosis of 26%–50% of liver cells and 4: necrosis of >50% of liver cells.

Microscopic and macroscopic types of peliosis hepatis were assessed separately by a semiquantitative method and expressed in a 4-degree severity scale (0–3): 0, no peliosis; 1, one zone of hepatic lobule (approximately 33%); 2, two zones of hepatic lobule (approximately 67%) and 3, all the hepatic lobule (approximately 100%).

Apoptosis was evaluated (a) using H&E stain for total apoptotic index and (b) in situ using the TUNEL assay for apoptotic index for hepatocytes and apoptotic index for nonparenchymal liver cells. Hepatic cell subpopulations were discriminated by their localization in the acini and by the immunochemical detection of vimentin. Apoptotic indices were expressed as the number of positive cells per 1000 cells.

Mitoses were counted in H&E stained sections at 10 high-power field (HPF) and expressed per 1000 liver cells. Inflammatory infiltration was also expressed as the number of inflammatory cells per 1000 liver cells.

sec.title: Immunohistochemistry for Kupffer cell detection
sec.p: Immunochemistry was carried out using APC Detection Kit for nonparenchymal cells (vimentin 1:50 plus microwave; NeoMarkers) and for activated Kupffer cells CD68 (1:50 plus microwave; NeoMarkers). Positive cells were counted at 10 HPF and expressed per 1000 liver cells.

Kupffer cells were identified by the immunochemical detection of F4/80 macrophage surface antigen. Slides were incubated with proteinase K (20 μg/mL) for 15 min at room temperature for antigen retrieval. Endogenous peroxidase activity was quenched by treatment of the slides with 3% hydrogen peroxide for 10 min. The slides were treated for 30 min with 5% normal rabbit serum in phosphate buffer saline-blocked nonspecific binding. Kupffer cells were then detected with a primary antibody to the F4/80 macrophage surface antigen (MCAP497, Serotec Inc, Raleigh, NC, USA). A biotinylated anti-rat secondary antibody (BA-4001, Vector Laboratories, Burlingame, CA, USA) specifically identified the primary antibody. The liver sections were then incubated with avidin and biotinylated horseradish peroxidase (HRP) and identified using the HRP substrate diaminobenzidine and counterstained with hematoxylin. Brown-staining cells with appropriate nuclear morphology and sinusoidal location were counted as Kupffer cells. Kupffer cells were quantified as the average number of F4/80-positive cells per field from at least 20 randomly selected fields per section.

sec.title: Serum enzymatic activity assays
sec.p: The biochemical evaluation of liver injury was assessed by quantifying serum activities of alanine aminotransferase (ALT) and aspartate aminotransferase (AST) using a random-access chemistry analyzer (RA-1000; Technicon Instruments Corp, Tarrytown, NY, USA)

sec.title: Hepatic regenerative activity
sec.p: The rate of liver regeneration was evaluated by the mitotic index in H&E sections and by the rate of tritiated thymidine incorporation into hepatic DNA.

sec.title: Rate of tritiated thymidine incorporation into hepatic DNA
sec.p: DNA was extracted from the tissue according to the method of Munro and Fleck (1966) as modified by Kyprianidis et al. (1996). The DNA concentration of the samples was estimated by the method of Richards (1974). The rate of 3H-thymidine incorporation into hepatic DNA was calculated from the radioactivity measured in a liquid scintillation counter (Wallac LKB 1211, Rackbeta, Sweden). Results were expressed as counts per minute per microgram DNA (cpm/μg).

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: Data are expressed as means ± standard error. All observations were obtained from at least six animals. The statistical analysis of the results was performed by one-way analysis of variance followed by Scheffe’s multiple comparison test.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Cadmium administration in group I rats caused evident liver necrosis which peaked at 12 and 48 h (Figure 1). Necrosis was zonal and located mainly at zone 2 in the hepatic acinus. The enzymatic activities of AST and ALT were elevated at 12 h and peaked at 48 h (Figure 2). GdCl3 administration (group II) reversed cadmium-induced necrosis. For all time points examined, necrosis was reversed in group II rats with the exception of 48 h, where relatively low grades of the lesion were observed (Figure 1). Serum levels of AST and ALT were significantly decreased by GdCl3 administration (Figure 2).

caption.p: Grade of liver necrosis as a function of time after acute cadmium intoxication in rats given with 6.5 mg CdCl2/kg body weight and normal saline (group I) or gadolinium chloride (10 mg/kg body weight 24 h prior to cadmium administration; group II). Results represent the findings in eight rats killed at 12, 16, 48 or 60 h and six rats killed at 0, 9 and 24 h. Values are expressed as means ± SE. ***p < 0.001, **p < 0.01, group I versus group II. CdCl2: cadmium chloride; SE: standard error.

Serum aspartate aminotransferase (AST) and serum alanine aminotransferase (ALT) activities as a function of time after acute cadmium intoxication in rats given 6.5 mg CdCl2/kg body weight and normal saline (group I) or gadolinium chloride (10 mg/kg body weight) 24 h prior to cadmium administration (group II). Results represent the findings in eight rats killed at 12, 16, 48 or 60 h and six rats killed at 0, 9 and 24 h. Values are expressed as means ± SE. +++ p < 0.001, ***p < 0.001, group I versus group II. CdCl2: cadmium chloride; SE: standard error.

sec.p: Hepatocyte apoptosis was also zonal (zone 2) in group I rats. Hepatocyte apoptosis (TUNEL assay) was maximal at 12 h with a second lower peak being observed at 48 h after cadmium intoxication in group I rats, whereas the apoptotic index was significantly decreased at 16, 24 and 60 h. Hepatocyte apoptosis was almost totally reversed in group II rats at all time points examined (Figure 3).

caption.p: Time course of apoptotic index demonstrated by TUNEL assay, for hepatocytes and for nonparenchymal liver cells after acute cadmium intoxication in rats given 6.5 mg CdCl2/kg body weight and normal saline (group I) or gadolinium chloride (10 mg/kg body weight) 24 h prior to cadmium administration (group II). Results represent the findings in eight rats killed at 12, 16, 48 or 60 h and six rats killed at 0, 9 and 24 h. Values are expressed as means ± SE. +++ p < 0.001, ***p < 0.001, ++ p < 0.01, + p < 0.05, group I versus group II. CdCl2: cadmium chloride; SE: standard error.

sec.p: Nonparenchymal cell apoptosis (Figure 3) in group I rats increased gradually between 9 and 48 h, where it peaked. Nonparenchymal cell apoptosis was totally attenuated by GdCl3 administration at all time points examined (Figure 3).

Liver inflammatory neutrophil infiltration and Kupffer cell activation, as studied by immunochemical detection of CD68, were minimal and close to control group values for both groups of rats at all time points examined (data not shown). Gadolinium pretreatment also eliminated F4/80-positive cells in rats of group II (data not shown).

Macroscopic peliosis hepatis was first detected at 16 h and peaked at 48 h in group I rats (Figure 4). For all time points examined, it correlated with nonparenchymal cell apoptosis. Macroscopic peliosis hepatis was almost totally reversed by GdCl3 administration in group II rats (Figure 4).

caption.p: Extent of macroscopic and microscopic types of peliosis hepatis as a function of time after acute cadmium intoxication in rats given 6.5 mg CdCl2/kg body weight and normal saline (group I) or gadolinium chloride (10 mg/kg body weight) 24 hours prior to cadmium administration (group II). Results represent the findings in eight rats killed at 12, 16, 48 or 60 h and six rats killed at 0, 9 and 24 h. Values are expressed as means ± SE. +++ p < 0.001, ***p < 0.001, ++ p < 0.01, + p < 0.05, group I versus group II. CdCl2: cadmium chloride; SE: standard error.

sec.p: Microscopic peliosis hepatis gradually increased in group I between 9 and 24 h, where it peaked, whereas the lesion was greatly decreased in group II, and it was almost totally reversed at 16 and 24 h (Figure 4). Mitotic index in group I rats commenced, increasing at 24 h and the index was still increasing at 60 h. The index was kept at low levels for all-time points examined in group II rats (Figure 5).

caption.p: Rate of liver regeneration as evaluated by mitotic index (MI) by H&E stain after acute cadmium intoxication in rats given 6.5 mg CdCl2/kg body weight and normal saline (group I) or gadolinium chloride (10 mg/kg body weight) 24 h prior to cadmium administration (group II). Results represent the findings in eight rats killed at 12, 16, 48 or 60 h and six rats killed at 0, 9 and 24 h. Values are expressed as means ± SE. **p < 0.01, group I versus group II. H&E: hematoxylin–eosin. CdCl2: cadmium chloride; SE: standard error.

sec.p: Tritiated thymidine incorporation into hepatic DNA was increased at 9 h in rats of group I and remained consistently elevated for all time points examined with the exception of 16 and 24 h (Figure 6). In rats of group II, tritiated thymidine incorporation into DNA was at higher levels between 9 and 24 h in comparison with group I and then dropped at the same levels as group I after 48 h. (Figure 6).

caption.p: Rate of liver regeneration as evaluated by tritiated thymidine incorporation into hepatic DNA after acute cadmium intoxication in rats given 6.5 mg CdCl2/kg body weight and normal saline (group I) or gadolinium chloride (10 mg/kg body weight) 24 h prior to cadmium administration (group II). Results represent the findings in eight rats killed at 12, 16, 48 or 60 h and six rats killed at 0, 9 and 24 h. Values are expressed as means ± SE. ***p < 0.001, **p < 0.01, group I versus group II. CdCl2: cadmium chloride; SE: standard error.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Cadmium acute hepatotoxicity represents a field of intensive scientific research, but despite this fundamental aspect, it remains unveiled. Apoptosis represents an essential mechanism for the elimination of critically damaged cells in the livers of cadmium-intoxicated rats and it seems to be more profound in nonparenchymal liver cells. The time pattern of apoptotic cell death was distinct for hepatocytes and nonparenchymal liver cells with hepatocyte apoptosis to evolve in a biphasic pattern and nonparenchymal cell apoptosis, a monophasic pattern. Nonparenchymal cell apoptosis also seems to be the main mode of cell death implicated in the genesis of peliosis, and the above findings are in agreement with the previous findings of our team (Tzirogiannis et al., 2003).

Cadmium appears to be directly toxic to hepatocytes and especially liver endothelial cells, which are considered the most sensitive liver cell population to the toxic effects of the metal (Tzirogiannis et al., 2003). Indirect actions of the metal through activation of Kupffer cells have also been reported (Rikans and Yamano, 2000). Since Kupffer cell activation has been minimal and close to control group for both groups of rats in our study, the observed hepatotoxic effect of the metal must be attributed to direct actions. Direct hepatotoxic effects of cadmium occur in the rough endoplasmic reticulum and in the nucleus (Dudley et al., 1984), and both endoplasmic reticulum stress and DNA damage are triggering the apoptotic cascade.

Increased reactive oxygen species (ROS) production has been proposed as the major mechanism for direct cadmium actions, and since cadmium is a redox-stable metal, free radical production must be mediated through indirect mechanisms (Liu et al., 2008). The metal depletes glutathione and protein-bound sulfhydryl groups, which results in increased production of ROS such as superoxide, hydroxyl radicals and hydrogen peroxide (Liu et al., 2008). These ROS result in increased lipid peroxidation, enhanced excretion of urinary lipid metabolites, increased levels of oxidative stress and finally DNA and membrane damage that trigger apoptosis (Liu et al., 2008).

Gadolinium pretreatment greatly attenuates all aspects of cadmium-induced acute hepatotoxicity, and this must be attributed to actions of gadolinium other than Kupffer cell elimination. Such an action has also been insinuated by the findings of others (Harstad and Klaassen, 2002b).

Caspase 3, a member of the caspase family or proteins, is an early effector of apoptosis and its levels closely correlate with the degree of apoptosis (Giammarioli et al., 2008). Gadolinium administration greatly reduces caspase 3 expression and this action has been attributed to Kupffer cell inactivation (Li et al., 2009). Interestingly, gadolinium also seems to directly inhibit apoptosis through downregulating caspase 3 pathway (Zhang et al., 2006).

In our study, gadolinium administration caused significant elevations in tritiated thymidine incorporation into hepatic DNA and in mitotic index values that persisted until 60 h after its administration. These results are in agreement with the findings of others (Dudley et al., 1982) and cannot be attributed to liver regeneration since liver necrosis has been minimal in the gadolinium pretreated group of rats. Gadolinium has been reported to increase liver cell turnover in the intact liver and this effect is not observed in liver cell cultures (Dudley et al., 1982). This effect of gadolinium is thought to be mediated by TNF-α production from dying Kupffer cells, although production from other cell types such as cells of the biliary epithelium and portal vein cells could also participate (Dudley et al., 1982).

In conclusion, gadolinium administration greatly attenuates all aspects of acute cadmium-induced hepatotoxicity through direct actions of the metal. Further research is needed at this point in order to fully elucidate the molecular biology of this lanthanide.
